newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Traders see 97/98 Australia wheat price down.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Traders see 97/98 Australia wheat price down.

text.p: A looming supply overhang of wheat due to Australia's 1996/97 bumper crop could result in a decline in the Australian Wheat Board's (AWB) first pool estimate price for 1997/98, grains traders said on Tuesday
The AWB's current pool price of A$185 a tonne is based on an estimated harvest of 21.5 million tonnes, the second largest ever for Australia.
An AWB spokesman said it will be early February before it announces its first pool estimate price for the 1997/98 harvest.
"At that time, we'll indicate what carry over we'll have, if any ... the sort of crop size we are anticipating," the spokesman said.
The value of the Australian dollar agains the United States currency also will help determine the price, he added.
"We put all those factors together," he said.
However, traders said that despite continuing export business, the size of the current crop would weigh on prices.
"We think the next pool that is opened up will be A$15 to A$20 (a tonne) lower for ASW (Australian Standard White) at around A$165," one said.
The traders estimate that so far about 50 percent of 1996/97 exports have been sold.
The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics sees Australian wheat exports at 13.34 million tonnes in 1996/97 versus 12.06 million tonnes in 1995/96.
"There are still a lot of exports going through," said one trader.
"Shipments from Australia are very tight until the end of January."
This is being underscored by a slight premium on wheat futures over physical shipments, delivered to the port of Newcastle in New South Wales State, another trader said.
"If you want to deliver wheat to Newcastle, you'll have difficulty booking freight unless you drive it there yourself," the trader said.

Nearby January wheat futures on the Sydney Futures Exchange (SFE) overnight screen trading system, SYCOM, were quoted at A$162.50 a tonne. Floor trading of wheat futures is scheduled to resume at the SFE on January 2, 1997.
